displayed_text: Patient: Okay, I’m good with that. That sounds good. Okay? Doctor: It’s okay. Patient: I happy with it. Doctor: Great. You guys had a lot of good questions today. Patient: We learned to ask. You got to speak up. That’s right. Doctor: You got to advocate for yourself. Right? That’s absolutely the one thing. So, very good. Patient: So, that’s good news that we can travel. I like being able to see the grandkids you know. Doctor: Yeah, yeah, and they’ll tell you exactly when and how long, you know, the kids, exposure, all of that he will explain. But we will start with giving you a side effects sheet and then I’ll have J____ come in and just tell J____, our nurse, Patient: Yeah, right. Doctor: about what to expect and how she’s going to do the prior authorization and then well we’ll kick you to the curb. Okay? Patient: Okay. Sounds good. Doctor: We’ll get out next one for I think it’s two months from now maybe for the shot. Family Member: Yeah. It will be the time for the Lupron.

Patient: I haven’t had chemo there. Doctor: But I’m talking scans. Patient: Scans. Yeah I’ve had scans at Hospital B and also Hospital C at O____ and also the Hospital A, so in M____. So you know it doesn’t make any difference really to me, yeah. Doctor: Great, I just want to make sure that they can be compared so that we can get a sense of what’s changed- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: because if everything’s stable even though your PSA is going up, we might wait longer. If the pictures show more cancer and your PSA is higher Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: you know and then that’s the information that says okay, what do we do next? Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know say I don’t like any of those trials that (names person) Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Yeah, well I’m in favor of the trials. Family Member: There are a lot more side effects with the trials.

Patient: Right. Doctor: Do you need a refill? Patient: Yes. Doctor: And then, huh, and then you have, and then the morphine you said right now you don’t need it? And how many ibuprofen do you take a day? Patient: Well, (laughs) Doctor: Four to six a day. Every six hours you can take it, so that would be, that’s thirty, (pause) Patient: Okay. Doctor: So there’s two, like I said, two knocks against you that may make, huh, everything that we just talked about, make it so that we’re not able to do it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, but then we can just, when I see you, plan what day you want to get chemotherapy started. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Does that make sense? Patient: Yep.

Family Member: Okay. Patient: And the way… Doctor: Okay. Family Member: You better do it. You better do it B____. You better do it. Patient: The way everybody’s been explaining it to me is that too many people can’t be writing you pain med prescriptions. Doctor: Correct. Well, and we only saw you to just check in. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If we got audited, it would be well, you’re not even taking care of him so what are you writing all this stuff for… Patient: Right. Doctor: …but you’re gonna be under our care for the study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we’ll just assume that at this point otherwise you’re driving here, you’re driving there, it makes no sense.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, it has less side effects than chemotherapy but has more risks than chemotherapy because if we do turn on your immune system really good, attack you, you could be bad. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay? Family Member: That’s if it ends up going bad versus -- uh, activated immune system. Doctor: We often use steroids, and we try to sort of dampen it – Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And some folks – most people recover. Uh, but we have to hold the drugs, not hold the drugs, and then, -- yeah, so it’s a catch twenty-two, uh, that, you know, it also is for individuals like you who again have some factor that tells us that your cancer is not gonna bode well with, you know, your survival from this cancer is not, you know, tremendously long. Patient: I, I was told I’ll see another Christmas. Doctor: Yeah. That could be true, or it could be a little bit longer. But, again, most of the time when we’ve used the docetaxel – the Taxotere that you got that you started in the fall? Uh. We tell folks that from that setting, we sort of says that people live fifteen to twenty months. Eh, so that’s when we may get to the end of this year. Uh. And so that’s where you also may step back and say, “Whoa. If time is short, I don’t want to be sick. I don’t want to have to go to the doctor. I don’t wanna be all of this other stuff. Uh. Let me focus on me.” Okay? And work on just keeping you comfortable. ‘Cuz right now, you’re comin’ and goin’, gettin’ exhausted at five o’clock. You’re takin’ your nap and – you know, getting your cleaning done the next day. Patient: Five. Yeah. So. Doctor: So, that is – some people do just sort of say, “Look. You know, I’ve been through everything, and I don’t know if I can do much more. And I wanna just sort of be comfortable.” Other folks say, “Okay. There’s more drugs? Give ‘em to me.” Okay? Patient: Yeah.

Family Member: So you can radiate? Doctor: We can radiate anywhere. Family Member: So in C___ Dr. F____ can radiate. Doctor: Dr. F____ can radiate it. If it’s needed. Now, he won't just willy nilly do it unless you have pain, or we've shown that everything about you is stable and those are the only two areas that’s acting up. Family Member: Well, that’s good to know that. I didn’t know that. Doctor: Yeah see you’re not just out there. Patient: Now I’ve got a question for you. Doctor: Yeah. Shoot. Patient: Nobody really explained to me what I will feel as this disease progresses- Doctor: Mmm. Patient: -as it changes and that I will detect the symptoms that I will. Doctor: Yeah. Well, the sheer fact that you are actually asking me that tells me that you don't have many symptoms, because people who have the symptoms, be it bone pain or just extreme fatigue or weight Loss, no appetite will tell me, “Oh man, look at all these things happening to me is because of my cancer?” So when you're curious, that means like, okay, none of this stuff is happening, which is great, but you worry about it because you think this is it, I'm gonna get bone pain. And this is it. You know, that's not the case. If you have pain in the bone, there are medicines to help or more importantly, there are techniques like radiation to help and there are other medicines that we can do to and other strategies to help the pain go away. So pain is usually what everybody worries about is number one, and then the other ones would be things like, you know, complete quality of life loss is, “I don't want to anything”

Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: The super hormones for the three months also make you more tired, but not really that much more because once we lower your testosterone down to what we call castrate levels, to go from castrate to super castrate, people don’t complain about more tiredness. Patient: Right. Doctor: So um there are some things we watch and your blood tests to make sure you’re tolerating the drugs all right, but that’s not the big issue. Tiredness is the issue. So then we add chemo in and really we give the chemo to you four times on a Monday – Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - three weeks apart. Um, the the actual um chemo itself, you don’t get sick, you don’t throw up. We have all the medicines that stop that from happening. Anything that throw up We’re just really good at it. Uhm, Patient: Sure. Doctor: And during that time you’re more tired is when your blood counts are low when you’re fighting infection. So we ask you not to travel on a plane those four days, if at all possible. If you do you have to wear a mask, and we ask you not to be around babies for those four days if possible because they’re infectious, not that you’re an injury to them. Patient: Right. Doctor: But other than that uh there really are no side effects. You may lose your hair temporarily. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, um, but it grows back. Um and you generally will only lose it for the last two doses. Patient: Okay.

Healthcare Professional: Just let me know when you’re done and I’ll come turn it off. Doctor: Okay, great. Thank you. Okay. Patient: Alrighty. Doctor: Okay. All right. So first we have to go over results. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So you have the CAT scan- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: -that showed probably no evidence of metastatic disease, okay, meaning no evidence of cancer that we can see. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: The reason why I say probably- did you get these results on MyChart? Patient: Nuh-uh. Doctor: Okay, are you are you on MyChart? Family Member: We are, but we didn’t go on there.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: My sense is that this really was a new baseline just to make sure we're, you know, again, it's unusual for this to be real. Patient: Right. Doctor: But it's a possibility. I mean I just had a patient just before you his PSA was point three, something showed up, we put a biopsy and guess what it was prostate cancer- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -but that's not the norm. It doesn't make sense. And yet that's an example where it shows possibility. Patient: Right. Doctor: So you know with you, you know what I worry about is sometimes you know, we write prostate cancer on the order form so the doctor over says, “Oh, yeah, there it is, there it is.” Patient: Okay. Doctor: And they may be right, or they may be calling what we normally if you had a scan and they’d say, “ that’s just arthritis, that’s just arthritis, that’s just arthritis”. Patient: Right. Doctor: Prostate Cancer likes to go to the lymph nodes, and so they're oft- they have to start small. And so we all have lymph nodes, but in this case, they say yeah, there’s lymph nodes-

Patient: Why did you say it wouldn’t be – you just don’t think they work? Doctor: Well just in all the other patients that have sort of done that, they need to do it with something else. It’s just not strong enough. Patient: Okay, yeah, okay. I can’t say it goes away you know Doctor: Mm hmm. Patient: maybe it calms me down Doctor: Yeah. Patient: and something like that too, but nothing that I’ve had right now and I, I, I I’m not consistent with it. Doctor: Sure. Patient: It’s just something that we’ve tried – Doctor: Right. Patient: - been recommended that we try and I think we brought it up but… Doctor: Yeah. You know cancer is cancer, it’s got its own set of pain.

Family Member: So we’re still kind of up in the air because this is nothing we can cure because of the type of cancer that it is and there’s no option to remove the lymph node. I don’t know Doctor: That’s correct. Family Member: That’s correct. Okay, okay. So with him trying to maintain quality of life and, and, and, uhm you know stay upright knowing that he has this and that he’s against hormone therapy but also still leaning with the fact that there’s the other foot to drop. Doctor: Uh hum. Family Member: You’re saying the radiation is a viable option if that’s the route he chooses to go but your recommendation is hormone? Doctor: No actually open to both; it all depends on your current wishes. If your wish is to preserve your quality of life as much as possible for as long as possible – Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - then there’s no question that hormone therapy will cause more side effects than radiation. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: There’s no question about that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, if your goal is to try to eradicate as much of the cancer as fast as possible –

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.10 or more times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::10 or more times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Retired: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Retired

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

Please feel free to leave any comments a.text_box: This was a lot of reading, and it was tough - and I say that as a former RN. Sometimes I had trouble figuring out what was being said, especially from the doctor. I did see a lot of evidence here of overwhelmed patients, which is completely understandable in this situation but does pose a challenge for *anyone* working in oncology. Some doctors are good at talking to patients; some aren't, and that showed here (I don't know if they get training in that but if they don't, they should). I will say I had trouble with the empathy rating because my understanding of the word is "feeling others' feelings" and that is not helpful in health care - you can't do your job if you aren't detached but sometimes (probably more with docs than others) you need to balance detachment with a bit of compassion. It is not an easy job.

displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. That’s a good point. Right. Doctor: Yeah. I mean, I think if you want to explore that, my feeling would be if you can get it on the study, well and good. If not, you should explore if you can go and, you know, I don’t know what it costs there, and, you know, what you have to pay. Family Member: If you can get on, on the study, which would involve the scan, doing the scan? Doctor: Doing the scan first. Family Member: Yeah. Of course. Doctor: But even there, they would do the scan first, because if it’s not going to help you, they’re not going to push you to get the treatment that’s not going to work. Family Member: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: And that’s one treatment every-? Doctor: Six weeks. Patient: Six weeks? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: For-?

Patient: Right. Doctor: If the decision says the insurance will cover it, after you’ve read it, huh, you could say, yeah, I’m interested. And then we’ll bring you back to have a formal discussion about what that looks like. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so all that can happen in the next three to four weeks. Huh, so you come off the abiraterone. We’ll see if this gets better. Watch your potassium. But you do some reading. Huh, if there’s other people you want to talk about the trial, people that have been on it, huh, or have any concerns about, you know, being here so much, let us know, because we can work on some of that with you. Patient: Now, the only thing, huh, mainly. The vitamin C, if I get it, I might not use something, and if I don’t get it, it ain’t going to affect the chemo I’m getting to try to do-? Doctor: Right. Because that’s what everybody gets. That’s what everybody gets. Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay? Patient: So. You know. Doctor: Yeah. It ends up boiling down to your time on this study. And again, someone close by or regional, it, it makes some sense, you know, huh, and you could always back out if it’s just too crazy to come in. You know? We’re are going to try to get you at least the first cycle of this to sort of get the data on you about side effects, what you’re feeling, what you’re not feeling, huh, and that. Huh, so it sounds to me like you’re open to the idea. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But we don’t have to commit today to sort of say, yeah, I’m doing it, huh, because we also have to check your insurance. Patient: Right.

Patient: It’s coming a long… Doctor: Yeah, yeah, but the cancer has stayed in check for a really long time with the chemo… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …so I think uh so far the chemo has done you good. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Alright. So today we’ll go ahead and I know you gave G____ the list of medications… Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Your blood pressure and stuff, we’ll send those in. Patient: Okay. Because I said my vitamins, that’s what, that boosts me up. Because like when I’m fatigued I can’t get up, I take one of those vitamins. Doctor: That helps. Patient: And I’m off and running. Yes sir. I’m off running man. Doctor: Now are you still taking prednisone?

Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: In case. Now, it wasn’t like you went all the way down zero and stayed there. So you were always around a one to two. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: You know? You’re in the fours a couple of times now, so. Patient: Um hum. Could it be because I’ll be in the sun a lot? Doctor: No. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Not that. You’re doing everything right. You are. Doctor: Everything from the music to showing up when you’re supposed to. You’re doing all the right things. Patient: Hum. Doctor: You really are. It’s just that the cancer doesn’t care. Patient: I get it.
